body_text.text: Coronaviruses (CoV), such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and 27

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), are of medical importance with high 28 mortality rates and significant zoonotic and pandemic potential. Here, we apply ribosome profiling 29 and parallel RNASeq to globally analyse changes in the host cell translatome and transcriptome 30 upon infection with mouse hepatitis virus, strain A59 (MHV-A59), a model murine coronavirus in 31 the same genus as SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV. We observed translational upregulation of ATF4, 32 ATF5 and Ddit3 and activation of the unfolded protein response (UPR). Phosphorylation of eIF2α 33 led to the global inhibition of translation and a substantial increase in empty 80S ribosomes. A drug 34 that inhibits the UPR attenuates virus growth suggesting that MHV may have evolved to subvert the 35 UPR to its own advantage. We also investigated an artefact of cycloheximide pretreatment in 36 ribosome profiling whereby ribosomes accumulate at the 5ʹ end of coding sequences in stressed We reasoned that some host genes may be resistant to virus-induced shut-off and that identifying 141 such genes might give new insights into the shut-off mechanism(s). To evaluate differences at the 142 level of translation as a result of MHV infection, we calculated relative translation efficiencies (TE) 143 -defined herein as the ratio of ribosome-protected-fragment (RPF) and total RNA density in the 144 coding region (CDS) of a given gene -at 5 and 8 h p.i. TE was estimated using Bayseq in the 145 paired library mode, Babel [32] and Xtail [33] . These analyses had few overlapping predictions of 146 genes significantly differentially expressed, with Xtail producing a much higher number of 147 predictions (Fig 2) . These differences are likely due to variations in model assumptions between the 148 different approaches and reflect the greater difficulty inherent in modeling a quotient distribution 149 (i.e. RiboSeq/RNASeq). It has particular applicability to virology 44 where it allows not only monitoring of viral gene expression, but also host response at the level of 45 individual genes and globally. In this work, we use ribosome profiling and parallel transcriptome 46 sequencing (RNASeq) to monitor changes in transcription and translation in cells infected with the 47 model coronavirus, murine coronavirus strain MHV-A59, a virus in the same genus as the 48 medically important SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV. The sensitivity and precision of the approach 49 permit us to obtain a high-resolution analysis of different biological processes -such as the 50 activation of the unfolded protein response. At late time points of infection, translation is inhibited 51 globally and, surprisingly, viral transcripts are not resistant to this effect. After cleavage, the amino-terminus of 224 ATF6, containing a basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transactivating domain, translocates to the nucleus 225 to upregulate the ER chaperone immunoglobulin heavy chain binding protein (BiP/Grp78), whose 226 mRNA or protein levels serve as a proxy for activation of the ATF6 pathway [29,49] 17 Cl-1 cells 227were infected with MHV-A59 or incubated with tunicamycin. Cells were harvested at 2.5, 5, 8 and 228 10 h p.i. and analyzed by qRT-PCR (Fig 5A). An induction of BiP/Grp78 transcription was 229 observed in tunicamycin-treated (purple) and MHV-infected cells (orange) from 2.5 to 8 h p.i. 230 followed by a modest decline, whereas mock-infected cells (blue) showed no induction.231 Surprisingly, whereas Western blot analysis (Fig 5B) confirmed induction of Bip/Grp78 protein in 232 tunicamycin-treated cells by 8 h p.i., no such induction was seen in MHV-infected cells. 233 234 At 8 h p.i., MHV-infected cells were harvested by flash freezing in the absence of cycloheximide. 235 As a positive control for UPR activation, cells treated with tunicamycin for 6 h were also harvested 236 by flash freezing. Activated IRE1α removes a 26-nt intron from unspliced Xbp-1 (Xbp-1u) mRNA 245 leading to a translational reading frame shift and a longer protein. The product of spliced Xbp-1 246 mRNA (XBP-1s) is an active transcription factor that upregulates the expression of ER-associated 247 degradation (ERAD) components and ER chaperones. Determination of Xbp-1 splicing was done by 248 reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) of total RNA extracted from 17 Cl-1 cells infected with MHV-249 A59 or incubated with tunicamycin, using specific primers flanking the Xbp-1 splice site (Fig 5D). 250 At all timepoints, Xbp-1u was the predominant form in mock-infected cells whereas Xbp-1s was the 251 major species in tunicamycin-treated cells. In virus-infected cells, Xbp-1u was predominant at 2.5 h 252 p.i. but Xbp-1s became predominant at 5 h p.i. In order to analyse translation of Xbp-1u and Xbp-1s 253 in virus-infected cells, we inspected the ribosome profiling data (Fig 5E). For 8 h p.i. MHV-infected 254 cells (Inf Ribo panel) and tunicamycin-treated cells (Tunica Ribo), an increased number of reads 255 mapped in the +2 reading frame (yellow peaks) of the Xbp-1u sequence, and downstream of the 256 annotated stop codon. These reads result from translation of the Xbp-1s frameshifted isoform and 257 indicate a dramatic increase in production of the active transcription factor. 258 259 Monitoring PERK-eIF2α -ATF4 activity 260 In response to ER stress, PERK oligomerizes and auto-phosphorylates [52]. Activated PERK 261 phosphorylates the α-subunit of eukaryotic initiation factor 2 (eIF2α) which in turn impairs 262 recycling of inactive eIF2-GDP to active eIF2-GTP resulting in a general shutdown of protein 263 synthesis [53]. To further investigate virus-induced inhibition of 296 translation as a consequence of UPR activation and eIF2α phosphorylation, analytical polysome 297 profiling (Fig 7A) was done for mock-and MHV-infected 17 Cl-1 cells. Cytoplasmic extracts were 298 prepared in the presence of cycloheximide to retain intact monosomes and polysomes and analyzed 299 by sucrose density gradient centrifugation. This revealed an accumulation of monosomes (80S) in 300 MHV-infected cells from 5 h p.i. onwards, consistent with inhibition of initiation. To investigate 301 whether the 80S ribosomes accumulating during MHV infection contain mRNA (as an indicator of 302 a translating ribosome), polysome profiling was repeated using a higher salt buffer (400 mM KCl; 303 Fig 7B), conditions in which 80S ribosomes lacking mRNA dissociate into constituent subunits. In 304 mock-infected cells, a modest diminution of 80S levels was observed at 400 mM KCl (mock 5 h, 305 compare Fig 7A panel 2, and Fig 7B left panel), but a much greater reduction in 80S was observed 306 in MHV-infected cells (MHV 5 h p.i., compare Fig 7A panel 5 and Fig 7B right panel), indicating 307 that the vast majority of 80S ribosomes accumulating at this time point are not mRNA-associated. 308 These data indicate that MHV-infection leads to translational shut-off via inhibited initiation, 309 consistent with the effects of eIF2α phosphorylation. 310 311 Effect of the PERK inhibitor GSK-260614 on MHV replication 312 GSK-260614 is a potent and selective high affinity ligand of the PERK kinase that interferes with 313 kinase activity by competing for ATP [55,56]. These observations suggest that relieving inhibition 325 of protein synthesis -affecting both cellular and viral proteins -is detrimental to virus production 326 and the development of syncytia in virus infected cells. used ribosome profiling and parallel RNASeq to investigate changes in the cellular 331 translatome and transcriptome in response to infection with MHV, a representative of the 332 Betacoronavirus genus of the Coronaviridae family. These studies provide the highest resolution 333 data to date on the translatome of cells during coronavirus-induced stress. 334 335 RNASeq libraries revealed that some of the most significantly upregulated cellular transcripts in 336 virus-infected cells were part of the UPR (Herpud1 and Chac1) and changes in the translation 337 efficiency of cellular proteins were consistent with uORF-regulated responses to eIF2α 338 phosphorylation, including those previously implicated as effectors of the UPR such as in Atf4, Atf5 339 and Chop [34-39]. These high-resolution data confirm again that there is a close interplay between 340 virus infection and the UPR, with the host activating the UPR to combat the effects of virus 341infection, and viruses sometimes manipulating the UPR to promote replication and pathogenesis modulation of UPR branches differs between different CoVs [3,5,66]. For example, 346 SARS-CoV infection does not lead to Xbp-1 splicing [46] whereas the IRE1 pathway is activated by 347 infectious bronchitis virus or MHV infection or by MHV S protein overexpression [29,67]. In spite 348 of the observed Xbp-1 mRNA splicing during MHV infection [29], Xbp-1s protein had not 349 previously been detected in coronavirus-infected cells. In our study (8 h p.i. data set), an increased 350 number of RPF reads mapped in the +2 reading frame of the Xbp-1u transcript corresponding to 351 translation of the Xbp-1s frameshifted isoform. 352 353 Activation of the ATF6 pathway by CoV infection has not yet been fully addressed. ATF6 cleavage 354 into its active form is observed during MHV infection but is significantly reduced at late time points 355 [29]. On the other hand, the trimmed ATF6 form is not detected in SARS-CoV infected cells [68]. 356 Furthermore, ER stress-responsive promoters exhibit little activity under these conditions. In the 357 present study, an induction of BiP/Grp78 transcription due to ATF6 activation was observed to a 358 similar extent in both tunicamycin-treated and MHV-infected cells, whereas BiP/Grp78 protein 359 expression was only detected by western blotting in tunicamycin-treated cells. Ribosome profiling 360 data revealed that, in virus-infected cells, the amount of RPFs corresponding to the BiP CDS was 361 not as high as in tunicamycin-treated cells and this was probably the reason why this protein was 362 not detected by western blot analysis. 363 364 With respect to the UPR-related inhibition mediated by eIF2α phosphorylation, it has been shown 365 that infectious bronchitis virus activates or suppresses protein kinase RNA-activated (PKR) and 366 PERK during the course of an infection [69] whereas transmissible gastroenteritis virus protein 7 367 emulates the function of DNA damage-inducible protein 34 (GADD34) to dephosphorylate .i. and a concomitant increase in translation of the main ORF. Although [29] failed to detect the 371 products of ATF4 target genes, Gadd34 and Chop, during MHV infection by western blotting, we 372 found evidence supporting an increase in transcription and translation of Chop at later time the effect of the selective PERK inhibitor GSK-260614 on MHV replication [55,56].376 GSK-260614 (IC 50 = 0.4 nM) exhibits >1000-fold selectivity for PERK over heme-regulated eIF2α 377 (HR1) and PKR. Up to 5 µM of this inhibitor was well tolerated by 17 Cl-1 cells and, in MHV-378 infected cells, the prevention of eIF2α phosphorylation alleviated the inhibition in translation of 379 cellular and viral proteins as expected. Surprisingly, the higher content of viral proteins did not lead 380 to a more prominent cytopathic effect but instead delayed syncytia formation and reduced viral titre. 381 Therefore, we conclude that UPR-mediated eIF2α phosphorylation may be favourable to MHV 382 replication -perhaps by preventing translation of various anti-viral factors -and the 383 pharmacological manipulation of this UPR branch can be explored as a potential target for analysis of RPFs mapping to host mRNAs during MHV infection [16] indicated a 387 remarkable perturbation in ribosome distributions at late time points, with a greatly increased 388 proportion of RPFs mapping to the first ~30-40 codons of coding regions. In yeast, it has been 389 reported that an accumulation of reads in the 5′ region of coding sequences specifically under cell 390 stress is an effect of cycloheximide pretreatment, and it has been hypothesized that stressed cells 391 might have a slower rate of cycloheximide uptake leading to increased mean post-initiation 392 ribosome run-on times prior to cycloheximide-induced arrest of elongation [43,44]. Thus, it was 393 unclear whether this artefact might also occur in mammalian cells given that mammalian cells lack 394 a cell wall. Our results show that this does indeed extend to mammalian cells and thus call into 395 question the interpretations put forward by [41] and [42] for the similar perturbations in ribosome 396 density observed when cells were subjected to heat shock or proteotoxic stress. Further, we find that 397 the magnitude of this artefact depends on the type of stress and, in the case of MHV infection, is not 398 alleviated by increasing the concentration of cycloheximide to 100 times the standard amount, but 399 can be alleviated completely by flash freezing without cycloheximide pretreatment. Since the 400 artefact also occurs in mammalian cells, it is possible that it is not related simply to cycloheximide 401 uptake rates. Potentially it may instead be related to dysregulation of the translational machinery 402 under stress in a way that reduces cycloheximide efficiency (e.g. due to alterations in ribosomal exit 403 (E)-site tRNA occupancy). 404 405 Ribosome profiling provides information on initiating and elongating 80S ribosomes but it does not 406 account for free monosomes or early stages in initiation prior to formation of the 80S complex. 407 Analytical polysome profiling showed an accumulation of 80S monosomes in MHV-infected cells 408 from 5 h p.i. with the vast majority not being associated with mRNA which is a typical outcome of 409 impaired translation [71]. This suggests that protein translation was inhibited at the stage of 410 initiation probably due to the activation of the PERK branch in response to ER stress and the 411 concomitant phosphorylation of eIF2α. Phosphorylated eIF2α (p-eIF2α) forms a stable complex 412 with eIF2B -the guanine exchange factor responsible for recycling inactive eIF2-GDP to eIF2-GTP 413 -which rapidly reduces the pool of available eIF2B. This prevents recycling of the ternary complex 414 of eIF2, GTP and Met-tRNAi and formation of the 43S pre-initiation complex, and thus leads to a 415 general shutdown of protein synthesis by inhibition of initiation [72]. 416 417 Viruses commonly employ translational shutoff mechanisms to facilitate viral replication. On the 418 one hand, shut-off of host cell translation can redirect the translation machinery towards viral gene 419 expression if the virus has evolved non-canonical modes of translation, such as internal ribosome 420 entry site (IRES) mediated initiation. On the other hand, the shut-off of host cell protein synthesis 421 will inhibit a range of cellular anti-viral responses. Previous studies have shown that MHV can 422 induce host translational shutoff and mRNA decay in LR7 cells with the concomitant formation of 423 stress granules and processing bodies [28]. Furthermore, a number of reports have demonstrated 424 that CoV nsp1, the most N-terminal product of the replicase polyprotein, modulates host protein 425 synthesis. In different CoVs, nsp1 has been shown to associate with the 40S ribosomal subunit thus 426 preventing viral and cellular mRNA translation; induce cellular mRNA degradation via an 427 endonucleolytic mRNA cleavage in the 5′ region of capped mRNA; and selectively target nuclear 428 host mRNAs and transport them to the cytoplasm for degradation [30-31,73-74]. The involvement 429 of nsp1 in host protein translation could not be ruled out in this study without a comparison with a 430 mutant virus lacking nsp1. However, the UPR-related translational modulation and the CoV nsp1-431 related modification of translation (and mRNA degradation) testify to the complexity of cellular 432 translational shutoff mechanisms utilized by CoVs. How MHV proteins can be synthesized in a 433 state of global translation inhibition has been the subject of previous speculation. Viral mRNAs 434 contain a common 5′-leader sequence (65-90 nucleotides long) that could bind to the nucleocapsid 435 (N) protein to form a complex that might act as a strong translation initiation signal [75], or the 436 leader RNA sequence may bind to nsp1, protecting the viral mRNAs from nsp1-induced RNA 437 cleavage [74,76]. However, we found previously that virus mRNAs 2-7 were translated with 438 generally similar efficiencies during infection and, importantly, were not preferentially translated 439 relative to host mRNAs. Thus we concluded that the synthesis of large quantities of virus proteins, 440 especially N, was achieved mainly through high levels of transcription [16]. 441 442 In conclusion, this study provides a survey of coronavirus effects on the cellular transcriptome and 443 translatome, complementing previous investigations on the UPR and host cell shutoff during MHV 444 infection. These results are 163 consistent with eIF2α phosphorylation (leading to inhibited initiation) being a major cause of host 164 translational shut-off during MHV infection. 165 An artefact of cycloheximide treatment explains a remarkable perturbation in the 167 distribution of elongating ribosomes 168 Previous meta-analyses of RPFs mapping to host mRNAs in MHV-infected cells indicated a 169 remarkable perturbation in host cell translation at late time points [16] with a greatly increased 170 proportion of reads mapping to the first ~30-40 codons of CDSs in MHV-infected cells at 5 and 8 h 171 p.i. (e.g. Fig 3A compares 8 h p.i. with 8 h mock; data from [16]). Other ribosome profiling studies 172 have revealed a similar accumulation of ribosomes in the 5ʹ portion of CDSs after heat shock, 173 proteotoxic and oxidative stress, and attributed this to an early post-initiation inhibition of 174 elongation under cell stress [40-42]. More recently, these results have been called into question by 175 the discovery that cycloheximide pre-treatment in yeast leads to an accumulation of ribosomes in 176 the 5ʹ portion of CDSs specifically in stressed cells [43,44]. Moreover, this accumulation was not 177 seen if the yeast cells were flash frozen without cycloheximide pre-treatment, or if very high 178 concentrations of cycloheximide were used. 179 180 In order to determine whether this experimental caveat might extend to stressed mammalian cells 181 and perhaps explain the observed accumulation of ribosomes downstream of initiation sites during 182 virus infection [16], 17 Cl-1 cells were infected with MHV A-59 at MOI of 10 and at 8 h p.i. 183 harvested either by flash freezing in the absence of cycloheximide, or following supplementation of 184 the growth medium with 100 µg/ml cycloheximide (CHX 1X) or 10 mg/ml cycloheximide (CHX 185 100X) for minutes prior to harvesting.
